heading: keeping disaster data offline
subheading: a house committee passes a bill to keep worst-case chemical disaster assessments off the internet. by louise knapp.
author: louise knapp
text: a bill that prohibits posting chemical disaster information on the internet sailed through the house commerce committee on thursday. the chemical safety information and site security act, introduced a year ago by committee chairman tom bliley (r-virginia), was prompted by concerns that making such sensitive information widely accessible could invite terrorist attacks.such worst-case disaster information is often part of the risk management plans mandated by the clean air act. the plans predict the impact such disasters would have on people and their surroundings.bliley said the bill, now headed back to the senate for action, would strike a balance between the need for national security and the need for communities to have access to disaster information.the proposal ensures that local authorities responsible for preventing, planning, or responding to chemical releases have immediate access to the data in order for them to plan for chemical disasters.
